title: 2026 Is My Year: The One Resolution That Actually Works for Menopausal Women
excerpt: Every January, I watch the same thing happen. Women walk in with their lists. Lose 20 pounds. Sleep better. Feel like myself again. By February, most have quietly abandoned all of it. Not because they lack willpower—but because menopause has changed the rules.

config.content:
Every January, I watch the same thing happen.

Women in my practice walk in with their lists. Lose 20 pounds. Sleep better. Get my energy back. Feel like myself again.

By February, most have quietly abandoned all of it.

I used to think they just needed better strategies. More accountability. A different approach.

I was wrong.
Before I explain what I've learned, I want to ask you something. Be honest.

config.question: How many Januarys have you made the same resolution?
config.resultsMessage: You're not alone. 58% of our community has been making the same resolution for 6+ years.

config.content:
If you picked that last option, I need you to hear something.

This isn't a willpower problem.

The women in my practice who've been fighting this battle for years? They're not weak. They're not lazy. They're some of the most determined, disciplined people I know.

They've raised families. Built careers. Held everything together when it felt like the world was falling apart. These women don't lack motivation.

So why does a simple resolution—eat better, move more, lose weight—collapse by Valentine's Day?

Look at the numbers.

config.content:
8%. That's it. And here's what bothers me about that statistic:

We've been told the problem is us. Not enough discipline. Not enough commitment. Not trying hard enough.

But what if the problem was never us?

What if we've been trying to build a house on a foundation that's already cracked?

Take this quick assessment. I want you to see something.

config.content:
If you checked 3 or more boxes, here's what's actually happening inside your body:

Menopause has fundamentally altered how you metabolize food. How you regulate energy. How you manage stress. Even how your brain processes motivation and reward.

And at the center of all of it—controlling more than you'd ever imagine—is your gut.

Specifically, something called the estrobolome: the collection of gut bacteria that regulates estrogen in your body. When menopause disrupts this system, your willpower is fighting a battle it literally cannot win.

You're not failing your resolutions. Your biology is sabotaging them before you even start.

Two Ways to Approach 2026

This is the choice I put in front of every patient who walks into my office in January.

The difference isn't motivation. It's not discipline. It's not wanting it badly enough.

The difference is where you start.

config.tip: You're not undisciplined. You're not lazy. You've been building resolutions on a broken foundation. Fix the foundation, and everything else becomes possible.

config.content:
I've heard this story hundreds of times. The details change—gym memberships, meal plans, walking goals—but the arc is always the same.

And every single time, the woman sitting across from me thinks it's her fault.

It's not. It was never her fault. The timeline was broken before she started.

Not stopped trying. Stopped fighting your biology.

I hear these objections every week. They're valid. They come from years of disappointment.

But there's one story I want to share in full, because Barbara said something that stuck with me for weeks.

config.headline: "For the First Time in Six Years, I Don't Feel Like I've Failed"
config.name: Barbara
config.quote:
I've made the same resolution every year since I turned 50: lose weight, get healthy, feel like myself again.

Every year I'd fail by February and spend the rest of the year feeling like a failure.

This year, Dr. Amy told me to forget all that. Just do one thing: support your gut first. Everything else later.

It's been three months. I haven't 'transformed.' But I have energy. I'm not bloated. I sleep through most nights. And for the first time in six years, I don't feel like I've failed.

That's what this gave me. Not a miracle. Just a foundation that finally holds.

config.content:
"For the first time in six years, I don't feel like I've failed."

Barbara didn't need to lose 20 pounds to feel successful. She needed to stop feeling like a failure. And that happened because she finally started in the right place.
